intro: Ferula tolucensis, commonly known as the Tolú licorice, is a perennial herb native to the tropical regions of South America, particularly Colombia and Ecuador. It belongs to the Apiaceae family, which includes carrots and parsley, and is characterized by its tall, branching stems and narrow, aromatic leaves. The plant produces yellowish-green flowers in umbels, typical of the family, and its roots are used in traditional medicine for their purported health benefits. Ferula tolucensis is also valued for its unique fragrance and is sometimes cultivated for aromatic purposes.
